overview: The purpose of this Act is to make the women's court pilot program in the first circuit permanent and establish a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [11] The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [11] The measure requires reports, establishes temporary positions, appropriates funds, and sunsets on 6/30/2028. [10]
appropriations: The committee has amended this measure by changing the appropriations to unspecified amounts to facilitate further discussion on the measure. [12] The Judiciary requests appropriations to allow the pilot project to be fully funded through fiscal year 2027-2028. [10] The Department of Health requests a budget of $221,788 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) to support the Kona division pilot program. [12]
assumptions_and_methodology: The proposal for the formation of a Kona Women’s Court program is a 3-year pilot project under the umbrella of the well-established Big Island Drug Court. [10] By developing KWC under the pre-existing drug court program, the KWC pilot project will use the established structures of drug court as its “backbone”. [10] The cost of incarceration of just one person for three years is $277,035.10 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), meaning if the program helps keep just six women out of prison, it will have paid for itself. [10] [10]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program, under the supervision of the big island drug court. [11] The Department of Health's role will be to provide screening and assessments of possible eligible participants for the program, including forensic mental health consultation and coordination. [10] The Department of Health requests one full-time equivalent Clinical Psychologist for $145,000 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) and one full-time equivalent Social Worker for $76,788 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) to support the pilot project. [12]
economic_impact: This investment in KWC will ultimately result in cost savings. [10] The average cost of housing an inmate in Hawaiʻi is $253 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) dollars per day, which totals $92,945 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) per year. [10] [10] Supportive services are far less costly than incarceration when a person reoffends. [10]
policy_impact: This measure makes the Women's Court pilot program in the First Circuit permanent by amending Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, to remove the repeal date. [11] It establishes a three-year Women's Court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court. [11] [10] The judiciary is also required to submit a report to the legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for women's court in the second and fifth circuits and Hilo division of the third circuit. [11]
revenue_sources: The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [11] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [11] No other revenue sources are specified in the provided documents. [11]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The Judiciary proposes a three-year pilot project with a total cost of $1,576,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] The requested cost for fiscal year 2025-2026 is $514,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), for fiscal year 2026-2027 is $547,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), and for fiscal year 2027-2028 is $515,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] [10] Year 1 costs include $175,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for a Women's Mental Health Professional, $100,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Womens Behavioral Health Beds, $85,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for a Kona Drug Court Probation Supervisor, $80,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for a Peer Specialist, $30,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for a Cultural Practitioner and Advisor, $25,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Moral Reconation Therapy, $10,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Increased Drug Testing, $5,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Training, and $4,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Technology. [10] [10] [10] Year 2 costs are similar, but training increases to $42,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for the Kona Team to attend the national All Rise conference. [10] [10] Year 3 costs are also similar, with no funding for training or technology, but includes $10,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt) for Program Evaluation. [10] [10] The bill establishes two temporary positions: one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor position and one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) peer specialist position. [11] The pilot program established in part III of the Act is set to be repealed on June 30, 2028. [11] The Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit is made permanent, which will have ongoing fiscal implications beyond the pilot period. [11]
operating_revenue_impact: This measure is not expected to have an impact on operating revenues.
capital_expenditure_impact: The Judiciary is seeking funding for technology to support program operations with a total cost of $4,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] This includes a Computer Workstation for $1,200 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), a Computer for the Kona Probation Supervisor for $1,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), a Printer for $1,000 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), a Cellphone for Field Work for $500 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), and a Laptop for Work in Rural Communities for $1,200 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt). [10] [10] All technology costs are requested for the first year of the pilot program. [10]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: The women's court pilot program in the first circuit is made permanent, which will require ongoing funding beyond the six-year period. [11] The pilot program in the Third Circuit is temporary and sunsets on June 30, 2028. [11] If the pilot program is successful, the ultimate goal would be to expand the women’s court program to Hilo and make the program permanent after the end of the 3-year project period. [10]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The appropriations in the measure have been changed from specified amounts to unspecified amounts to facilitate further discussion. [12] The Judiciary's testimony has been updated to reflect a three-year pilot project, with a total proposed budget of $1,576,900 (HB727_SD1_TESTIMONY_WAM_03-31-25_.PDF.txt), an increase from the previously proposed two-year budget. [10] [10] The Department of Health has submitted a new request for $221,788 (HB727_SD2_SSCR1531_.htm.txt) to support the Kona pilot with a full-time Clinical Psychologist and Social Worker. [12]
